Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ATD: Integrated statistical algorithms with ultra-high performance computing for discovering SNPs from massive next-generation metagenomic sequencing data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recently, the emerging new field of metagenomics facilitated by the advent of next-generation sequencing technology enables genome sequencing of unculturable and often unknown microbes in natural environments, offering researchers an unprecedented opportunity to delineate bio-diversity of any microbial organism. Mining single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) from metagenomic sequencing data offers an unique opportunity to rapidly and accurately detect known or novel strains related to multiple biothreat agents. While the sequencing technologies are evolving at unprecedented speed, researchers engaged in this enterprise are facing major computational, algorithmic and statistical challenges in the analysis of the massive metagenomic data. It is clear that both current analytical and computational methods are inadequate for this challenge. In this project, the investigator and his colleagues develop a family of statistically sound and computationally efficient algorithms to detect SNPs from metagenomic data to characterize microbial diversity in natural environments.

The proposed project provides the national security and biodefense agencies new tools for rapid and accurate detection of biothreat agents. It also provides researchers in microbiology with new tools for producing abundant, high throughput SNPs for detailed analysis of the genetic basis of microbial diversity and evolution. Since this informatics tool can be used to study a wide variety of microbial communities, it helps accelerating scientific advancements of our knowledge in microbiology and evolution. The multidisciplinary nature of the project will promote collaboration between biologists, computer scientists and statistician. The multidisciplinary nature of the project will also provide postdoctoral fellows and graduate students training in statistics, genomics and scientific computing through hands-on experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metagenomics is the study of the collective genome (metagenome) of microorganisms sampled directly from natural environments. Sequencing-based metagenomics involves high-throughput sequencing of the whole genome of all microbes in the environment, allowing us to rapidly dissect uncultured bacterial communities and metabolism pathways associated with microbial community at a high resolution, i.e., "Who is there and what are they doing".

While the sequencing technologies are evolving at unprecedented speed, the analysis of the massive metagenomic data is computationally, algorithmically and statistically challenging. The research supported by this award has resulted in a pipeline of statistically rigorous and computationally efficient algorithms for metagenomic data analysis. Specifically, we have developed SIX high performance statistical packages that include  (1) "REMix" for fast and accurate base calling for metagenomic sequence data; (2) "MetaMat" and "DirichletCluster" for reference free metagenomic data binning; (3) "MultiGeMS" for SNP detection from metagenomic sequence data; (4) "MetaBoot" for taxonomical biomarker discovery for different microbial communities based on metagenomic sequence data; and (5) "Strain-GeMS" for optimized subspecies identification from metagenomic sequence data. We also developed various subsampling techniques and multiple comparison procedures to address the computational issues and multiple testing problems encountered in base calling, SNP calling, biomarker discovery and binning on metagenomic sequence data. Our work fills in a void in the lack of an integrated high-performance computational pipeline that distills extraordinary large and complicated metagenomic data to characterize microbial diversity in natural environments and to accelerate our knowledge in microbiology and evolution. The multidisciplinary nature of the research promoted collaboration among biologists, computer scientists and statisticians as well as provide postdoctoral fellows and graduate students training in statistics, genomics and scientific computing.
